meanings.definition: Physical or mental collapse caused by overwork or stress.
meanings.sent1: After working long hours for weeks, she experienced burnout and needed a break.
meanings.sent2: The doctor advised him to take time off to prevent burnout from affecting his health.
meanings.sent3: When the computer programmer's brain reached burnout, he started making errors in his code.
meanings.sent4: The athlete felt like he was on the brink of burnout, unable to push himself any further.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's burnout was evident in her tired eyes and lack of enthusiasm.

meanings.definition: The reduction of a fuel or substance to nothing through combustion.
meanings.sent1: The burnout of the candle left nothing but a small puddle of wax.
meanings.sent2: The burnout of the firewood produced a warm glow in the fireplace.
meanings.sent3: The burnout of the matchstick was so quick, it surprised the child.
meanings.sent4: The burnout of the rocket's fuel propelled it into the sky with great force.
meanings.sent5: The burnout of the engine caused the car to come to a sudden stop.

meanings.definition: The failure of an electrical device or component due to excessive heat.
meanings.sent1: The technician explained that the burnout of the fuse was the reason for the power outage.
meanings.sent2: The burnout of the light bulb was followed by a brief moment of darkness.
meanings.sent3: The burnout of the toaster made breakfast preparation more challenging.
meanings.sent4: The burnout of the computer's processor led to a complete system shutdown.
meanings.sent5: The burnout of the motor caused the machine to come to a sudden halt.
